Package voltage.core

Class VoltageLine

java.lang.Object
voltage.core.VoltageComponent
voltage.core.VoltageLine
public class VoltageLine
extends VoltageComponent
Line class with optional arrow head.

  • Field Summary

    Fields inherited from class voltage.core.VoltageComponent

    componentName, displayName

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    float GetArrowLength()
    returns the length of the arrow (parallel to the line's direction) in pixels; only applicable if the line has an arrow
    float GetArrowWidth()
    returns the width of the arrow (perpendicular to the line's direction) in pixels; only applicable if the line has an arrow
    int GetEndX()
    Returns the x position of the line's end point.

    Returns the y position of the line's end point.

    Returns the x position of the line's starting point.

    Returns the y position of the line's starting point.

    returns true if this line has an arrow drawn at its endpoint

    • SetHasArrow

      public void SetHasArrow​(boolean ha)
      if true, the line will have an arrow drawn at its endpoint; call SetArrowWidth() and SetArrowLength() to set the size of the arrow
      Parameters:
      ha - true/false

    • SetArrowWidth

    • GetLineWidth

      public float GetLineWidth()
      Returns the line's thickness in pixels
      Returns:
      the line's thickness in pixels

    • GetStartX

      public int GetStartX()
      Returns the x position of the line's starting point. Note that the line object's bounding rectangle will usually be larger than the bounding rectangle of the line's start and end points because it needs to account for line thickness and arrow size, so GetStartX() and GetEndX() (which refer to line endpoints) often won't return the same values as GetX() or GetRect() (which refer to the line object's bounding rectangle).
      Returns:
      the line's start x.

    • GetStartY

      public int GetStartY()
      Returns the y position of the line's starting point. Note that the line object's bounding rectangle will usually be larger than the bounding rectangle of the line's start and end points because it needs to account for line thickness and arrow size, so GetStartY() and GetEndY() (which refer to line endpoints) often won't return the same values as GetY() or GetRect() (which refer to the line object's bounding rectangle).
      Returns:
      the line's start y.

    • GetEndX

      public int GetEndX()
      Returns the x position of the line's end point. Note that the line object's bounding rectangle will usually be larger than the bounding rectangle of the line's start and end points because it needs to account for line thickness and arrow size, so GetStartX() and GetEndX() (which refer to line endpoints) often won't return the same values as GetX() or GetRect() (which refer to the line object's bounding rectangle).
      Returns:
      the line's end x.

    • GetEndY

      public int GetEndY()
      Returns the y position of the line's end point. Note that the line object's bounding rectangle will usually be larger than the bounding rectangle of the line's start and end points because it needs to account for line thickness and arrow size, so GetStartY() and GetEndY() (which refer to line endpoints) often won't return the same values as GetY() or GetRect() (which refer to the line object's bounding rectangle).
      Returns:
      the line's end y.

    • HasArrow

      public boolean HasArrow()
      returns true if this line has an arrow drawn at its endpoint
      Returns:
      true/false.
